node.title: Helmet worn by Amelia Earhart on 1928 flight sells for $825,000
node.description: Amelia Earhart wore the cap on a flight across the Atlantic in 1928 and later lost it in a crowd of fans in Cleveland.

node.title: More human remains found in search for Tulsa race massacre victims
node.description: In1921, a White mob descended on the Black section of Tulsa and burned over 1,000 homes and destroyed its thriving business district.

node.title: Police searching for man with 12 warrants for his arrest
node.description: Police are asking the public for information to help find David Johnstone, who has 12 outstanding warrants for his arrest.

node.title: States start probe of TikTok's impact on young users' mental health
node.description: Government officials and child-safety advocates worry about TikTok's practices and computer-driven promotion of content they say can endanger the physical and mental health of young users.

node.title: China asked Russia to delay Ukraine invasion for Olympics -NYT
node.description: Chinese officials told Russian official not to invade Ukraine before the end of the Winter Olympics in Beijing, The New York Times says.

node.title: Health workers' strikes off after Employment Court grants injunction
node.description: Strikes by health workers planned for tomorrow and next month have been called off after an Employment Court ruled in favour of District Health Boards.

node.title: Russian, Belarusian athletes banned from Winter Paralympics, after all
node.description: The International Paralympic Committee changed its mind in less than a day after fierce pushback in light of Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.

node.title: Fuel and commodity prices on the rise as Russia hit with sanctions
node.description: It might be happening on the other side of the world but the economic shockwaves of the Russian invasion of Ukraine are reaching New Zealand consumers.

node.title: Ukraine: Russia expected to resort to siege tactics as UN demands withdrawal
node.description: An explosion has rocked a Kyiv railway station where thousands of women and children were being evacuated, Ukraine's state-run railway company says.

node.title: Mental health should be priority as cases surge among students - psychologist
node.description: University students feeling anxious and uncertain about the Covid-19 outbreak should try not to become totally preoccupied by the pandemic, a psychologist says. Audio

node.title: Sprinter dashes across the Tasman to compete in nationals
node.description: Young sprinter Eddie Osei-Nketia has made a quick trip across the Tasman to compete at the National Athletics Championships in Hastings this weekend.

node.title: Russian athletes allowed to compete at Winter Paralympics
node.description: Russian and Belarusian athletes can compete as neutrals at the Winter Paralympics in Beijing despite widespread calls to ban them.

node.title: Protesters scatter around Wellington as clean-up continues
node.description: Anti-mandate protesters remain scattered in different groups around the Wellington area, as the clean-up of Parliament grounds continues. See how the day's events unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

node.title: Supreme Court upholds human trafficking, slavery convictions
node.description: The country's highest court has upheld the convictions of the first ever person to be convicted of both human trafficking and slavery in New Zealand.

node.title: Jan. 6 committee says it has evidence Trump, allies engaged in "criminal conspiracy"
node.description: The filing also said Trump "repeatedly asked the Vice President to exercise unilateral authority illegally."

node.title: 'Unacceptable': Kāinga Ora breached political neutrality - Commissioner
node.description: Government housing agency Kāinga Ora failed to remain politically neutral, the Public Service Commissioner has found.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 23,183 new community cases, 503 in hospital
node.description: There are 23,183 new community cases of Covid-19 being reported today, with 503 people in hospital, including seven in intensive care.

node.title: Failure of Otago building company signals tough times for construction sector
node.description: The failure of a South Island building company may be a sign of things to come for the construction sector.

node.title: 'We feel mamae': Wellington iwi look to heal desecrated parliament
node.description: Wellington tangata whenua Wednesday's riot at Parliament was painful to witness, calling it further desecration of their mana and whenua. Audio

node.title: 'Incompetent and negligent': Advocate hits out as $3m fund for victims not spent
node.description: Not a cent of a new $3 million fund for victims of serious crimes has been spent despite applications opening up seven months ago.

node.title: Arab refugees see double standards in Europe's embrace of Ukrainians
node.description: Syrian refugee Ahmad al-Hariri, who fled the war in his country for neighbouring Lebanon 10 years ago, spent the last decade hoping in vain to escape to a new life in Europe.

node.title: Joshua James, Oath Keepers member, pleads guilty to seditious conspiracy in January 6 investigation
node.description: Joshua James admitted that leader Stewart Rhodes told the group to prepare to use "lethal force" against anyone who tried to remove former President Trump from office. He will also cooperate with investigators.

node.title: 'We are near to a humanitarian catastrophe': Russian forces claim control of key port city
node.description: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has taken a heavy toll on civilians as residential neighbourhoods were bombed and key cities surrounded.

node.title: Judge temporarily bans Texas from investigating family over gender-affirming care
node.description: The ruling comes in response to a lawsuit filed against Governor Greg Abbott over an order he enacted that treats gender-transitioning procedures as child abuse.

node.title: Hybrid workers the happiest and most innovative employees - study
node.description: Covid has ushered in the era of hybrid working, with fewer long and expensive commutes, more time with family, and a chance to work the hours that suit, according to a two-year study.

node.title: Future of protests at Parliament to be reconsidered - Grant Robertson
node.description: As damage to Parliament's grounds and surrounding streets is assessed the future of protest in New Zealand will have to be reconsidered, the deputy PM says, and a researcher urges people to consider… Audio

node.title: Whangārei facing $25m water income loss as Marsden Point oil refining ends
node.description: The Marsden Point oil refinery closure will mean more than $25 million lost water income for Whangārei in the next decade

node.title: Arrest resulting in head injury unlawful - IPCA
node.description: The arrest of a man using excessing force and resulting in a head injury was not justified, an investigation has found.

node.title: Lack of mechanisms to govern chemical use in NZ - Commissioner
node.description: The country is flying blind on environmental harm from tens of thousands of chemicals, a new report says.

node.title: Cable connecting Tongan islands could take year to fix
node.description: Tonga Cable Ltd says the country's domestic telecommunications cable may take up to a year to fix.
